content.description:
JAPANESE FUMI-E (“STEPPING-ON PICTURE”), A TYPE OF METAL PLATE CARVED WITH CHRISTIAN IMAGERY, USED BY THE JAPANESE GOVERNMENT TO IDENTIFY SUSPECTED CHRISTIANS, CIRCA 1630

Heritage Images / Contributor

Japanese authorities required suspected Japanese Christians to tread on fumi-e plates based on the belief that Christians would refuse to disrespect images of Jesus Christ and other Christian religious figures.
content.question: The use of objects such as the one shown in the image best illustrates which of the following historical processes from 1450 to 1750 ?

choices.label: Some Asian states sought to limit foreign encroachment in their internal affairs.
Political leaders in Asia commissioned works of art to legitimize their rule.
Religious conversion by state rulers was often followed by the mass conversion of state populations.
The territorial expansion of Asian land-based empires limited European influence in many parts of Asia.

content.answer: Some Asian states sought to limit foreign encroachment in their internal affairs.
